review.title: Tracking Human-like Natural Motion Using Deep Recurrent Neural Networks
review.abstract: Kinect skeleton tracker is able to achieve considerable human body tracking performance in convenient and a low-cost manner. However, The tracker often captures unnatural human poses such as discontinuous and vibrated motions when self-occlusions occur. A majority of approaches tackle this problem by using multiple Kinect sensors in a workspace. Combination of the measurements from different sensors is then conducted in Kalman filter framework or optimization problem is formulated for sensor fusion. However, these methods usually require heuristics to measure reliability of measurements observed from each Kinect sensor. In this paper, we developed a method to improve Kinect skeleton using single Kinect sensor, in which supervised learning technique was employed to correct unnatural tracking motions. Specifically, deep recurrent neural networks were used for improving joint positions and velocities of Kinect skeleton, and three methods were proposed to integrate the refined positions and velocities for further enhancement. Moreover, we suggested a novel measure to evaluate naturalness of captured motions. We evaluated the proposed approach by comparison with the ground truth obtained using a commercial optical maker-based motion capture system.

sections.heading: A. Experimental Setup
sections.text: We implemented the algorithm proposed in this paper with MATLAB and the Microsoft Kinect SDK 2.0 on Window 8 OS. All experimental tests were performed on a PC with an Intel Core i5 1.8GHz processor and 4GB of RAM. Microsoft Kinect SDK 2.0 can extract skeletal data at about 30 frames per second (fps). For supervised learning and evaluation, we provided an OptiTrack motion capture system that features a range of ground hits and motion detection. Kinect sensor and motion capture system tracks simultaneously with the capture of time, we can construct sets of input and target pairs. Kinect sensor motion capture system is extrinsically calibrated.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: The aim of this work was to propose a method for improving the Kinect skeleton, which vibrates at self-closure and is discontinuous, to a human natural movement. To this end, we first used deeply recurring neural networks to refine the position and speed errors of the skeletal positions, then proposed three methods for integrating improved articular positions and speeds. In addition, we proposed a novel measure for assessing the naturalness of recorded movements. We evaluated the proposed methods against the truth gathered from a commercial motion detection system, and compared the results with those of the Kinect skeleton and several variants of our methods. Our proposed three approaches performed significantly better than the Kinect skeleton tracker, and the proposed integration methods result in a further improvement than if we only refine the Kinect skeleton data with pDRNN.
